title: 109_s2205
content:
The Act titled "Blunt Reservoir and Pierre Canal Land Conveyance Act of 2006" is referred to as the short title. It pertains to the conveyance of land related to the Blunt Reservoir and Pierre Canal. The Blunt Reservoir and Pierre Canal Land Conveyance Act of 2006 defines key terms related to the Blunt Reservoir feature, Commission, nonpreferential lease parcel, and Pierre Canal feature. The Blunt Reservoir and Pierre Canal Land Conveyance Act of 2006 defines terms related to the Pierre Canal feature, preferential leaseholder, and preferential lease parcel for the Bureau of Reclamation leases in 2001. The Blunt Reservoir feature and Pierre Canal feature are defined in the Blunt Reservoir and Pierre Canal Land Conveyance Act of 2006. The Act deauthorizes the Blunt Reservoir feature and defines terms such as unleased parcel, Secretary, and State. The Blunt Reservoir feature is deauthorized, and the State may accept ownership of certain features and liabilities associated with them. The State may accept ownership of certain features and liabilities, including expired easements and responsibilities as the agent for the Secretary in administering purchase options for preferential leaseholders. Outstanding obligations will bind the State, and conveyances or sales will be subject to reserved oil, gas, and mineral rights. The Act allows for the conveyance of permits, licenses, leases, and rights to a third party, subject to reservations and conditions specified in previous legislation. Preferential leaseholders have the option to purchase the preferential lease parcel from the Secretary or the Commission. Preferential leaseholders have the option to purchase the preferential lease parcel from the Secretary or the Commission on specified terms, including a cash purchase option. The value of the parcel for preferential leaseholders is determined under specific terms, with a ten percent deduction. The preferential leaseholder can purchase the parcel with 10 percent down and the rest paid over 30 years at 3 percent interest. If the parcel is under $10,000, it must be purchased in cash. The leaseholder has 5 years to exercise the purchase option. The value of a preferential lease parcel is determined by its fair market value for agricultural purposes, less 25 percent, in accordance with federal land acquisition standards. Any disputes over the value will be resolved following specific regulations. If a preferential leaseholder fails to purchase a parcel within the specified period, the Secretary will offer to convey it to the South Dakota Department of Game, Fish, and Parks for wildlife habitat mitigation. Proceeds from land sales will be deposited as miscellaneous funds in the Treasury. Proceeds from land sales under the Pick-Sloan project will be deposited as miscellaneous funds in the Treasury. The funds will be available to the State for establishing a trust fund to pay county taxes on lands received by the South Dakota Department of Game, Fish, and Parks. The Secretary will offer to convey nonpreferential lease parcels and unleased parcels of the Blunt Reservoir and Pierre Canal to the South Dakota Department of Game, Fish, and Parks for wildlife habitat mitigation within one year of the enactment of the Act. The South Dakota Department of Game, Fish, and Parks will use conveyed land for wildlife habitat mitigation lost due to the Pick-Sloan project. Land exchanges for nonpreferential lease parcels at Blunt Reservoir or Pierre Canal can be allowed with concurrence. The right to exchange nonpreferential lease parcels or unleased parcels at Blunt Reservoir or Pierre Canal is granted in a specific order of priority. The United States reserves a perpetual easement for water conveyance structures as a condition of the land exchange. The United States will not be liable for damages related to any parcel conveyed under this Act, except for acts of negligence committed before the conveyance date. This section does not increase the liability under the Federal Tort Claims Act. During the interim period, the Secretary will lease preferential and nonpreferential lease parcels under existing terms. Within 180 days of enactment, parcel descriptions will be provided to the State. The Secretary will transfer archeological collections to the State at no cost. The Secretary will transfer archeological and cultural items from the Blunt Reservoir and Pierre Canal features to the South Dakota State Historical Society without cost. $750,000 is authorized for expenses related to implementing the Act, with additional funds available to reimburse the Commission and State Department of Game, Fish, and Parks.
